explanation:
Needed symbols and why they matter for checking "no unreachable code":

- mhd_assert
  - The function contains mhd_assert calls that may expand to code invoking __builtin_unreachable or otherwise terminate execution. You must know the macro/implementation to decide whether paths guarded by mhd_assert are actually reachable or compiled out.

- __builtin_unreachable
  - Present in the static call graph as a callee of the target. If mhd_assert expands to call __builtin_unreachable, that makes subsequent code formally unreachable; its semantics must be known to judge MISRA violation.

- struct MHD_NonceNc
  - The code reads nn->nonce[noncelen], nn->nc and nn->nmask. You need the struct layout (nonce array length, types of nc/nmask) to determine bound safety and whether the assertions that precede certain branches can ever be falsified or are UB (which affects reachability reasoning).

- MAX_DIGEST_NONCE_LENGTH
  - Used in an early check that bounds noncelen. Its value relative to the MHD_NonceNc nonce buffer size determines whether accesses to nn->nonce[noncelen] are in-bounds (and thus whether the mhd_asserts and following branches can genuinely be executed).

- get_nonce_timestamp
  - The control flow depends on its boolean return. If it can return false for valid slot contents the branch with mhd_assert(0) is reachable; if it never returns false the mhd_assert path is unreachable. You must inspect its implementation/contract.

- MHD_strx_to_uint64_n_
  - get_nonce_timestamp calls this helper (seen in call graph). Its behavior (success/failure cases, parsing rules) is needed to decide when get_nonce_timestamp can fail and thus whether the mhd_assert path is reachable.

- TRIM_TO_TIMESTAMP
  - Used to compute ts_diff and compare against thresholds. Its definition (any wrapping/trimming behavior) affects which timing branches are possible and whether certain branches are reachable.

- REUSE_TIMEOUT
  - The comparison REUSE_TIMEOUT * 1000 >= ts_diff controls a branch. Its numeric value (or range) is needed to determine if that branch can be taken.

- struct MHD_Daemon (fields: nonce_nc_size, nnc, nnc_lock)
  - The function reads daemon->nonce_nc_size, indexes daemon->nnc, and locks daemon->nnc_lock. You need the types/sizes/semantics to confirm that nn is a valid slot, and whether the early returns (e.g., mod == 0) or indexing can make later code unreachable or undefined.

- get_nonce_nc_idx
  - Index selection into daemon->nnc depends on this function. Its behavior and return range determine which nn slot is selected and whether accesses (and thus the assertions/branches) are meaningful or can be skipped/unreachable.

(These symbols together let an analyst determine whether any branch in check_nonce_nc is impossible to reach given definitions/values, whether assertions introduce __builtin_unreachable calls, or whether undefined behavior makes code effectively unreachable — all necessary to assess the MISRA "no unreachable code" rule.)
